comments.body_markdown: Just to narrow in on one thing: `Callable<V>` is a generic type. You should never be declaring anything to be a callable, but rather, callable-of-something. Callable-of-Integer (`Callable<Integer>`), or callable-of-list-of-string (`Callable<List<String>>`), and then returning that type, and then doing something with it somewhere else. If you don't want to return anything or do anything with it, just use `Runnable`. The executor service will happily take a runnable task to perform.
comments.body: Just to narrow in on one thing: Callable<V> is a generic type. You should never be declaring anything to be a callable, but rather, callable-of-something. Callable-of-Integer (Callable<Integer>), or callable-of-list-of-string (Callable<List<String>>), and then returning that type, and then doing something with it somewhere else. If you don't want to return anything or do anything with it, just use Runnable. The executor service will happily take a runnable task to perform.

Then I'm doing second /follow to monitor another file. It works only for 2,3 saves for each file. After few changes in file it looks like thread which follows the file is killed. In listener method I looped the thread to start watching the same file again

My FileController

public class FileController {
    private final FileService fileService;
@PostMapping("/follow")
    public ResponseEntity startFollowFile(@RequestBody PathModel path) throws Exception {
        return fileService.fileFollower(path.getPath());
    }

My FileService class

@Service
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class FileService {
    @Autowired
    @Qualifier("fixedThreadPool")
    private final ExecutorService executorService;


    public ResponseEntity fileFollower(String pathProvided) throws Exception {
        File f = new File(pathProvided);
        if (f.isFile()) {
            List<Future<List<String>>> futures = new ArrayList<>();

            futures.add(executorService.submit(new MonitorChangesTask(pathProvided)));


            return new ResponseEntity<>(HttpStatus.CREATED);

} else {
            throw new FileNotExist(pathProvided);
        }
    }
}

My MonitorChangesTask class

@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class MonitorChangesTask implements Callable {
    private final String pathProvided;

@Override
    public Object call() throws Exception {
        String s1 = pathProvided.replaceAll("\\\\", " ");
        String[] split = s1.split(" ");
        StringBuilder directory = new StringBuilder();
        int counter = 0;
        for (int i = 0; i < split.length - 1; i++) {
            String s = split[counter];
            counter++;
            directory.append(s).append("\\");
        }
        listener(split, directory);
        return new Object();
}

 private void listener(String[] split, StringBuilder directory) throws Exception {
        Path path = Path.of(directory.toString());
        try (final WatchService watchService = FileSystems.getDefault().newWatchService()) {
            final WatchKey watchKey = path.register(watchService, StandardWatchEventKinds.ENTRY_MODIFY);
            while (true) {
                final WatchKey wk = watchService.take();
                for (WatchEvent<?> event : wk.pollEvents()) {
                    final Path changed = (Path) event.context();


 if (changed.endsWith(split[split.length - 1])) {
                        call();

 }
                }
            }
        }
    }

}

Why it stops following file after few saves of file? Something must be wrong with looping.

answers.body_markdown:
JPA is an abstraction over the database and is generalized for all databases. And we have stuffs which are database specific, like;

    OFFSET 5 ROWS
    FETCH FIRST 5 ROW ONLY

For info, IBM DB2 does not support these.

So JPQL, in general, will not usually support them. 

I guess native query is the way or you can work with `pageable`; `PageRequest` is a good implementation of pageable.
answers.title: How to get n rows at a time with JPQL?
answers.body:
JPA is an abstraction over the database and is generalized for all databases. And we have stuffs which are database specific, like;

OFFSET 5 ROWS
FETCH FIRST 5 ROW ONLY

For info, IBM DB2 does not support these.

So JPQL, in general, will not usually support them.

I guess native query is the way or you can work with pageable; PageRequest is a good implementation of pageable.

comments.body_markdown: Why is `writeToFile` taking a `HashMap` instead of a `Map`, and why is it a raw type? It seems to me it should be declared as `writeToFile(Map<String, Integer> averageTime)` which would fix your problem. Don't use raw types; always specify the type parameters of generic types (except on the right hand side when creating them, when you can abbreviate them as `<>`, using the "diamond syntax"). And prefer interfaces over concrete types for parameters.

answers.title: Typecast failed for iteration HashMap, expected object
answers.body:
Your Map is <String, Object>. So if You want to print the time you can do a simple Object.toString(). If You want to save the time as an Integer you need to cast From Object to Integer.

public static void writeToFile(HashMap averageTime) {
    try {
        File file = new File("newfile.txt");
        if (!file.exists())
            file.createNewFile();
        PrintWriter pw = new PrintWriter(file);
        for (Map.Entry<String, Object> entry : averageTime.entrySet()) {
            pw.println("IP: " + entry.getKey() + "AverageTime: " + entry.getValue().toString());
        }
